string.text: Standard 12-gauge cartridge filled with 6 mm shot (40 pcs.). Highly lethal at close range. Only suitable for use with smoothbore weapons.

12-gauge cartridge with a hollow-point bullet. It is normally used for hunting big game, but is also good for other purposes. Instead of piercing, this hefty slug weighing 39 grams simply crushes through armour.
Dart bullet. Its fins add stability, resulting in increased accuracy. The massive steel body of the bullet can penetrate any body armor.

In 1951 the Soviet Army adopted the Makarov 9mm pistol and its cartridge, the 9x18mm. The steel core bullet in a lead jacket combines the cheapness of lead with good penetrative capabilities for non-metal targets. It cannot pierce an armored vest with steel plates.

Penetrating cartridge with the impulse and size of a regular 9x18 PM cartridge. Developed by the Tula Design Bureau. At 11 meters it has a 100% likelihood of penetrating body armor with 2.4 mm armor plate and kevlar underlayer. At 30 meters it penetrates a 1.25 mm thick titanium plate and 30 layers of kevlar.

The 9mm Parabellum (better known in North America by the name of its designer, George Luger, as the 9mm Luger) is the only cartridge that has earned the simple title of "9mm cartridge" in its more than century-long life. The good ballistic qualities of the 9x19 cartridge have made it the standard ammunition for pistols and submachine guns in most countries.

One modification of the 9mm Parabellum cartridge is the 9x19+P+, which means high barrel pressure. This type of cartridge is used by police and, less frequently, by "civilian" pistols. Effective against armored targets.

The 5.7x28mm pistol cartridge was created in 1986 as a replacement for the 9x19mm Parabellum. Compared to the 9x19mm cartridge, it provides better accuracy, less recoil, longer effective range, greater armor penetration, and reduced ricochet. This cartridge filled the niche between pistol and intermediate cartridges. The 5.7x28 mm cartridge is used in the FN P90 personal defense weapon and the FN Five-seven.
5.7x28 AP is a cartridge with a hollow-point bullet, which has less penetration than the SS190, but greater stopping power and lethality.

The .50 Action Express (also .50 AE, 12.7 x 33, 12.7x32.6mm) is a cartridge developed in 1988 for the Israeli Desert Eagle. One of the most powerful single pistol cartridges in the world. Its massive hollow-point bullet gives this cartridge enormous stopping power.
Magnum is a cartridge of increased power compared to a regular cartridge of the same caliber. The name is also shared by a gun designed for a cartridge of this type.

The .45ACP (Automatic Colt Pistol) cartridges with a jacketed bullet has remained popular for over a hundred years. Its heavy bullet with a relatively weak powder charge does not have a high velocity, but has a significant stopping effect. It is used against personnel and light unarmored vehicles.

Federal's .45ACP (Automatic Colt Pistol) caliber ammo with the Hydra-Shock bullet is known for its high stopping power and has been the standard ammunition for this caliber for many years. Hydra-shock remains a good choice today.
Regular 5.45x39mm (index 7H10) army cartridges. Thanks to the reduced recoil and the higher muzzle velocity, this cartridge offers greater accuracy.
5.45x39mm cartriges with armor-piercing bullet (index 7H22). The cartridge contains a bullet with a carbide core. Effective against body armor.

A heavy bullet cartridge designated SS109 was developed in the 1980s in Belgium by the Fabrique Nationale. It was originally developed for the FN FNC assault rifle and the FN Minimi light machine gun. By the mid-1980s this cartridge was adopted as standard by all NATO countries.

The Nato 5.56x45mm cartridge caliber with an armor-piercing bullet with increased penetration. Known as P112. Effective against body armor. Widely used in small arms of NATO armies and special forces.

Special sniper cartridge. Its subsonic velocity allows it to be used in silenced weapons for special operations. Due to its caliber it has high stopping power, and due to the special heavy bullet design it pierces most body armor at ranges up to 200 meters.

A cheap modification of the specialized armor-piercing cartridge. Its subsonic velocity allows it to be used in silenced weapons for special operations. The bullet has a heat-strengthened steel core, which allows it to pierce most armor at ranges up to 200 meters.

Specialized cartridge with an armor-piercing bullet. Its subsonic velocity allows it to be used in silenced weapons for special operations. Due to its caliber it has a high stopping effect, and thanks to the special design of the bullet, a partially open hardened steel core, it penetrates most body armor at ranges of up to 400 meters.
Soviet 7.62mm caliber pistol cartridge. Contains a simple all-metal bullet.
Soviet 7.62mm caliber pistol cartridge. Contains a bullet with steel core, with improved armor-piercing capability.
Soviet 7.62mm rifle cartridge. Contains a simple all-metal bullet.
Soviet 7.62mm caliber rifle cartridge. Contains a bullet with steel core, with improved armor-piercing capability.
Standard NATO 7.62 caliber rifle cartridge. Contains a simple all-metal bullet.
Standard NATO 7.62 caliber rifle cartridge. Contains a bullet with steel core, with improved armor-piercing capability.
The standard army sniper cartridge. Contains a hollow point bullet with a steel core. The cheapest version of the sniper cartridge.

Specialized sniper cartridge. The cartridge is similar to the 7H1 sniper cartridge in terms of accuracy, but significantly exceeds it in armor-piercing capability due to the use of a pointed hardened steel core in the bullet design.
Cartridges with an armor-piercing bullet. The bullet has a hardened steel core. Designed for engaging personnel behind light armored cover at ranges of up to 500 m.
This cartridge were designed as a special sniper cartridge for long-range shooting, but today it is also widely used by hunters and sport shooters.

The 12.7x55mm STs-130 is a Russian-made rifle cartridge, developed at the TsKIB SOO for low-noise and flashless destruction of protected targets and personnel with heavy body armor at ranges of up to 600 meters.

12.7x99mm (12.7x99mm NATO or the.50 BMG) is a high-caliber NATO cartridge. It was developed in the 1920s as ammunition for the Browning M1921 heavy machine gun. After World War II, the cartridge was standardized by NATO and is produced by various NATO member states according to standardized specifications.

A battery composed of a projectile and an energy cell for the electromagnetic "Gauss" rifle. 2mm pellets are used as projectiles. Uses a capsulated fragment of the "Flash" artifact as the power source.
A homemade battery for the electromagnetic "Gauss" rifle. Due to its shoddy construction, the capacity has been reduced.
Cartridges with a high penetration bullet. The bullet contains a hardened steel armor piercing core. It is designed to hit personnel behind light armored cover at ranges of up to 500 m.

A high-explosive fragmentation anti-personnel rocket-propelled grenade, colloqually called the "Pencil". Allows hitting a concealed target at a distance exceeding the throwing range of a hand grenade. Equally effective against both infantry as well as lightly armored vehicles.
A defensive hand grenade, its shrapnel can pierce medium armor in a radius of 20 m.
An offensive hand grenade with a small lethal radius. The blast radius is about 5 m.
A smoke hand grenade. Designed for creating a smoke screen. It takes around 10 seconds for the cloud of smoke to form.
A chemical illumination grenade. Designed to illuminate parts of the terrain during night combat, as well as for blinding and disorienting the enemy. It lasts for less than a minute.
The 40mm VOG-25 (7P17) grenade is an explosive charge held in a single case. The propellant is ignited at the back of the grenade and shot out of a grenade launcher.

The 40mm VOG-25P or "Foundling" (7P24) grenade is a fragmentation grenade used in grenade launchers. Its main difference to the regular grenade is the warhead fuse, which causes the grenade to "bounce" upon impact with the ground and making it subsequently burst in the air, thus increasing its lethality.
The ARGES 40mm LV HE/FRAG 92 grenade. High explosive fragmentation grenade, with a self-destruct fuse in the tail section. The radius of effective shrapnel damage is about 5 m.
Telescopic scope for the Israeli IMI Galil rifle.
Telescopic scope with fixed optics and variable magnification. Usually mounted on hunting rifles and designed for easy aiming when firing. They are mounted on rifles with special brackets.

The USP-1 standard rifle scope is designed for rapid fire from AK74N, AK-74M, AK-94 and RPK-74N and PKMN machine guns during daylight and at night at luminous and illuminated targets. 1P29 is an index of the USP-1 of the State Artillery Directorate of the USSR Ministry of Defense. It was created as part of the Tulpan R&D project, from which it got its name.

The 1P78 Scope is designed to be fitted to assault rifles and submachine guns. The scope has a 2.8X magnification and an optical layout similar to that of the 1P77 scope. Designed by "Tochpribor" Central Design Bureau (Novosibirsk). The chief designer is S.I. Mikhalenko.S

1PN93 "Shorty" is a series of Russian night-time scopes designed for battlefield observation and low-visibility shooting. The series was developed in the 1990s by the "Tochpribor" Central Design Bureau, and manufactured by the Novosibirsk Instrument Production Plant. The design is modular, which allows to deploy various types of rifle scopes for a wide range of small arms at a minimal cost.

The Cobra scope allows for reliable shooting in natural lighting conditions (bright sunlight, deep twilight and moonlit night) due to 16 levels of manual brightness settings. The alignment of the crosshair and the target enables the shooter to shoot with one or two eyes, providing unlimited field of vision for effective rapid-fire shooting against fast-moving, small and sudden targets appearing for short periods of time.
EO Tech is the world leader and exclusive manufacturer of holographic systems for small arms.

"C-More Railway" open type Collimator sight can be instantly mounted on the "Weaver" or "Picatinny" mount. This scope can therefore be used with almost any weapon - shotgun, rifle, revolver, crossbow, paintball and airsoft rifles. The scope housing is made of aluminum.

DOCTER collimators are excellent modern optical devices. Thanks to their small size and weight as well as their compact, tubeless design, they have a wide range of applications for both hunting and sport. Reliable performance, high magnification, attractive design and fail-safe operation even under extreme weather conditions make the DOCTER sight indispensable.

The PK-A Collimator sight is a modern lightweight, sealed, easy to use sight for the "Tiger" hunting rifles, which have a side rail for the installation of optical sensors. The sight is intended for accurate aiming on AK74N, RPK74N, AKMN-1 and RPKN-1 rifles, when shooting under various lighting conditions - in the daytime at dusk, in poor visibility and rapidly changing illumination. The sight is sealed and filled with nitrogen to prevent fogging of the internal optical surfaces.

ELECTRO SIGHT 1x22x33 collimator sight for fast shooting. Shockproof, suitable for all types of weapons with a picatinny rail. The selectable brightness level of the backlight (7 levels) allows the scope to be used in different light levels.
Barska RED DOT 2x30mm closed collimator sight. Multi-coated optics, 100% waterproof, fogging resistant. Suitable for all types of weapons with picatinny rail.
The most popular Soviet-made telescopic scope. A dovetail mount is used to mount it on the gun.

PSO-1M2-01 is a scope for the high-precision shooting of the VSS and VS 9mm special sniper rifles. The scope is designed for firing at a distance of 100 meters up to 400 meters (in increments of 50 meters). It features a reticle backlight for shooting in the dark. A standard AA-type battery is now used instead of the 2RTs63 battery.
Fixed magnification 2.7x telescopic scope. It is optimized for mid-range combat as well as for use in urban environments. It uses a dovetail mount for mounting on a weapon.
The 1PN58 (HSPUM-2) passive electro-optical device is designed for observation and shooting at night. It is mounted on the weapon using the "dovetail" type mount.
This scope has a variable magnification and a target acquisition and illumination system. It is designed for use by special task forces. It uses a dovetail mount for mounting on weapons.

SUSAT L9A1 is an acronym for Sight Unit, Small Arms, Trilux (scope attachment for melee weapons with "Trilux" illumination). Most often used for small arms shooting at medium and long ranges. It is mounted on the Picatinny rail.
Telescopic ACOG scope, Trilux (scope attachment for melee weapons with "Trilux" illumination). Most frequently used for small- and medium-range small-arms fire. It is mounted on the Picatinny rail.
Telescopic ACOG-D scope - Trilux, Dusk (scope attachment for melee weapons with "Trilux" illumination for dusk). Designed for close combat in low light conditions. Mounted on the Picatinny rail.

Telescopic ACOG-N scope - Trilux, Night (scope attachment for melee weapons with "Trilux" illumination with integrated night vision device). Designed for fighting in zero light conditions. Mounted on the Picatinny rail.

Telescopic ACOG-RF scope - Trilux, RangeFinder (scope attachment for melee weapons with "Trilux" illumination with adjustable rangefinder). Allows adjusting the magnification for increased accuracy. It is mounted on the Picatinny rail.
Silencer attachment for 9mm pistols and submachine guns.
Silencer attachment for FN P90 personal defense weapon.
Silencer attachment for the OTs-33 "Pernach" pistol.
Silencer attachment for Glock and FN FNP pistols.
Silencer attachment for the SR-3 rifle.
Tactical automatic rifle silencer, known as the ATG.It is designed to reduce the sound and flash when firing the 5.56mm AK102 and 7.62mm AK103 and AK104 Kalashnikov rifles.
"TGP-A-5,45" tactical silencer for AK series automatic rifles.
PBS-1. Device for silent and flashless shooting from a Kalashnikov rifle.
PBS-4. Device for silent and flashless firing of 5.45mm shortened Kalashnikov assault rifle (AKS-74U).
Device for silent and flashless shooting from the SVD.
Silencer attachment for NATO 5.56x45mm assault rifles, as well as for 11.43x23mm pistols and submachine guns.
Device for silent and flashless firing of the SR-25 semi-automatic sniper rifle.

%c[255,1,255,255]ï%c[default] VOG-25, VOG-25P grenades
 
Single-shot, underbarrel "Kostyor" grenade launcher for assault rifles used in the Warsaw Pact countries. It's a simple single-shot launcher, with a manual safety and automatic locking mechanism to prevent firing in the case of improper loading.

%c[255,1,255,255]ï%c[default] M209 grenades
 
Underbarrel single-shot grenade launcher with Picatinny bar mount.

%c[255,1,255,255]ï%c[default] M209 grenades
 
The underbarrel grenade launcher developed by the German weapons company Heckler & Koch to replace the HK 79. The launcher is attached to the HK G36 rifle.

%c[255,1,255,255]ï%c[default] Cobra EKP-1C-03, Cobra EKP-8-02, 1P29 "Tulpan", PCO-1M2-01 scopes
 

%c[255,1,255,255]ï%c[default] Silencer for 9¿-91/VSK-94
 
The 9A-91 is a gas operated, rotating bolt weapon, which utilizes a long stroke gas piston, located above the barrel, and a rotating bolt with 4 lugs. The firing mechanism allows for single shots and continuous bursts.

The 9mm Stechkin automatic pistol was developed by designer I. Ya. Stechkin in the late 1940s and early 1950s and adopted for service by the USSR Armed Forces in 1951, simultaneously with the Makarov pistol. The APS is designed to be used by officers directly involved in combat operations as well as by soldiers and NCOs of some special units.

%c[255,1,255,255]ï%c[default] Cobra EKP-1S-03, Kobra EKP-8-02, 1œ29 "Tulpan", PSO-1 scopes
 

%c[255,1,255,255]ï%c[default] GP-25 underbarrel grenade launcher
 
A modern assault rifle designed to replace the aging AK-74. One of the main features is the ability to fire in two round bursts with high accuracy (at a distance of one hundred meters, both bullets hit the same spot). This significantly increases the chances of destroying the target thanks to the combined stopping and penetrating effect of the bullets.

%c[255,1,255,255]ï%c[default] Cobra EKP-1S-03, Cobra EKP-8-02, 1P29 "Tulpan", PSO-1 scopes
 

%c[255,1,255,255]ï%c[default] GP-25 underbarrel grenade launcher
 

%c[255,1,255,255]ï%c[default] TGP-A silencer
 
This rifle is based on the traditional layout (magazine front position), with rotating bolt and gas operated automatic loading system. The rifle is chambered for the 5.45x39mm cartridge, but it is also available in 7.62x39mm (AEK-973) and 5.56mm NATO (AEK-972).

%c[255,1,255,255]ï%c[default]ACOG, Barska ES AC10632, Barska Red Dot AC11090, C-more Railway Tactical, EOTech scopes
 

%c[255,1,255,255]ï%c[default] GP-25 underbarrel grenade launcher
 

%c[255,1,255,255]ï%c[default] PBS-1 silencer
 
The AK-12 is a Russian-made Kalashnikov assault rifle from 2012, a promising development of the Kalashnikov Concern. The development of the new assault rifle was carried out proactively since June 2011 under the leadership of Izhmash Chief Designer Vladimir Viktorovich Zlobin based on the developments of the previous 10 years. The assembly and testing of the first prototype fifth-generation Kalashnikov assault rifle with the working title AK-12 was completed in 2011.

%c[255,1,255,255]ï%c[default] scope installation is not possible due to the lack of a dovetail mount
 

%c[255,1,255,255]ï%c[default] GP-25 underbarrel grenade launcher
 

%c[255,1,255,255]ï%c[default] PBS-1 silencer
 
The 7.62mm Kalashnikov assault rifle (AK) is an assault rifle adopted for service in the USSR in 1949. The AK and its modifications are the most common firearms in the world. It is estimated that this type (including licensed and unlicensed copies, as well as third-party AK-based designs) accounts for up to 1/5 of all firearms on earth.

%c[255,1,255,255]ï%c[default] scope installation is not possible due to the lack of a dovetail mount
 

%c[255,1,255,255]ï%c[default] GP-25 underbarrel grenade launcher
 

%c[255,1,255,255]ï%c[default] PBS-1 silencer
 
AKS (GRAU index - 56-A-212M) is a variation of AK with a hinged metal buttstock, designed for airborne troops. It was adopted simultaneously with the AK. It was initially produced with a stamped receiver, but since 1951 it was milled.

%c[255,1,255,255]ï%c[default]Cobra EKP-1S-03, Cobra EKP-8-02, 1P29 "Tulpan", PSO-1 scopes
 

%c[255,1,255,255]ï%c[default] GP-25 underbarrel grenade launcher
 

%c[255,1,255,255]ï%c[default] TGP-A silencer
 
The Kalashnikov caliber 5.45mm automatic rifle, developed in 1970 by designer M.T. Kalashnikov and adopted for service in the USSR Armed Forces in 1974. It is a further development of the AKM. The development of the AK-74 is associated with the transition to the new intermediate 5.45x39mm cartridge.

%c[255,1,255,255]ï%c[default] scope installation is not possible due to the lack of a dovetail mount
 

%c[255,1,255,255]ï%c[default] GP-25 underbarrel grenade launcher
 

%c[255,1,255,255]ï%c[default] TGP-A silencer
 
The Kalashnikov caliber 5.45mm automatic rifle, developed in 1970 by designer M.T. Kalashnikov and adopted for service in the USSR Armed Forces in 1974. It is a further development of the AKM. The development of the AK-74 is associated with the transition to the new intermediary 5.45x39mm cartridge.

%c[255,1,255,255]ï%c[default] GP-25 underbarrel grenade launcher
 

%c[255,1,255,255]ï%c[default] integrated TGP-A silencer
 
The Kalashnikov caliber 5.45mm automatic rifle, developed in 1970 by designer M.T. Kalashnikov and adopted for service in the USSR Armed Forces in 1974. It is a further development of the AKM. The development of the AK-74 is associated with the transition to the new intermediary 5.45x39mm cartridge.

%c[255,1,255,255]ï%c[default] GP-25 underbarrel grenade launcher
 

%c[255,1,255,255]ï%c[default] TGP-A silencer
 
The Kalashnikov caliber 5.45mm automatic rifle, developed in 1970 by designer M.T. Kalashnikov and adopted for service in the USSR Armed Forces in 1974. It is a further development of the AKM. The development of the AK-74 is associated with the transition to the new intermediary 5.45x39mm cartridge.

%c[255,1,255,255]ï%c[default] Cobra EKP-1S-03, Cobra EKP-8-02, 1P29 "Tulpan", PSO-1 scopes
 

%c[255,1,255,255]ï%c[default] GP-25 underbarrel grenade launcher
 

%c[255,1,255,255]ï%c[default] TGP-A silencer
 
AK-74M is a modernized AK-74. It is equipped with a plastic folding stock and a universal mount (dovetail rail) for mounting sights, both telescopic and night sights, on the left side of the receiver. Thus, AK-74M replaced four AK-74 models at once: AK-74, AK-74N and AKS-74N.

%c[255,1,255,255]ï%c[default] GP-25 underbarrel grenade launcher
 

%c[255,1,255,255]ï%c[default] TGP-A silencer
 
Camouflaged Kalashnikov assault rifle with PK-A on an MTK-83 bracket.

%c[255,1,255,255]ï%c[default] ACOG, Barska ES AC10632, Barska Red Dot AC11090, C-more Railway Tactical, EOTech scopes
 

%c[255,1,255,255]ï%c[default] GP-25 underbarrel grenade launcher
 

%c[255,1,255,255]ï%c[default] ATG silencer
 
Two new Kalashnikov AK-101 (standard) and AK-102 (small) assault rifles were developed for sale in the West and third world countries for the standard 5.56mm NATO cartridge SS 109. The most noticeable difference between these assault rifles is the shape of the plastic magazine, which is straighter than magazines for Soviet cartridge caliber 5.45 or 7.62mm.

%c[255,1,255,255]ï%c[default] ACOG, Barska ES AC10632, Barska Red Dot AC11090, C-more Railway Tactical, EOTech scopes
 

%c[255,1,255,255]ï%c[default] ATG silencer
 
Two new Kalashnikov AK-101 (standard) and AK-102 (small) assault rifles were developed for sale in the West and third world countries for the standard 5.56mm NATO cartridge SS 109. The most noticeable difference between these assault rifles is the shape of the plastic magazine, which is straighter than magazines for Soviet cartridge caliber 5.45 or 7.62mm.

%c[255,1,255,255]ï%c[default] Cobra EKP-1S-03, Cobra EKP-8-02, 1P29 "Tulpan", PSO-1 scopes
 

%c[255,1,255,255]ï%c[default] GP-25 underbarrel grenade launcher
 

%c[255,1,255,255]ï%c[default] ATG silencer
 
The AK103 is an export version of the AK-74M assault rifle, differing in its use of 7.62x39mm (Soviet cartridge from 1943). AK103 can use AK/AKM magazines.

%c[255,1,255,255]ï%c[default] Cobra EKP-1S-03, Cobra EKP-8-02, 1P29 "Tulpan", PSO-1 scopes
 

%c[255,1,255,255]ï%c[default] ATG silencer
 
AK104/AK105 are modifications of AK-103 and AK74M respectively, with the barrel shortened by 101mm. The intermediate barrel length (between AK74M and AK-74U) allowed for reduction of the overall length of the gun, while leaving the chamber in the same place relative to the barrel breech as in the AK74M, without moving it back (as in the AK-74U). This resulted in better standardization of the entire "100th" family.

%c[255,1,255,255]ï%c[default] Cobra EKP-1S-03, Cobra EKP-8-02, 1P29 "Tulpan", PSO-1 scopes
 

%c[255,1,255,255]ï%c[default] TGP-A silencer
 
AK104/AK105 are modifications of AK-103 and AK74M respectively, with the barrel shortened by 101mm. The intermediate barrel length (between AK74M and AK-74U) allowed for reduction of the overall length of the gun, while leaving the chamber in the same place relative to the barrel breech as in the AK74M, without moving it back (as in the AK-74U). This resulted in better standardization of the entire "100th" family.

%c[255,1,255,255]ï%c[default] Cobra EKP-1S-03, Cobra EKP-8-02, 1P29 "Tulpan", PSO-1 scopes
 

%c[255,1,255,255]ï%c[default] GP-25 underbarrel grenade launcher
 

%c[255,1,255,255]ï%c[default] PBS-1 silencer
 
The automatic rifle, which replaced the AK in the Soviet army in 1959 and is its further development.

%c[255,1,255,255]ï%c[default] Cobra EKP-1S-03, Cobra EKP-8-02, 1P29 "Tulpan", PSO-1 scopes
 

%c[255,1,255,255]ï%c[default] GP-25 underbarrel grenade launcher
 

%c[255,1,255,255]ï%c[default] PBS-1 silencer
 
Variation of the AKM with a folding buttstock. The stock mounting system has been modified compared to the AKS (folding down and forward, under the receiver). This modification was designed specifically for paratroopers.

%c[255,1,255,255]ï%c[default] Cobra EKP-1S-03, Cobra EKP-8-02, 1P29 "Tulpan", PSO-1 scopes
 

%c[255,1,255,255]ï%c[default] GP-25 underbarrel grenade launcher
 

%c[255,1,255,255]ï%c[default] TGP-A silencer
 
AKS-74 is a variation of the AK-74 with a triangular metallic buttstock that folds sideways. Designed for use by airborne troops (a rifle without a folding buttstock cannot be conveniently and safely stored in the parachute harness).

%c[255,1,255,255]ï%c[default] Cobra EKP-1S-03, Cobra EKP-8-02, 1P29 "Tulpan" scopes
 

%c[255,1,255,255]ï%c[default] PBS-4 silencer
 
The shortened AK-74 assault rifle was developed in the late 1970s and early 1980s for use in combat vehicles, aircraft and by gun crews as well as paratroopers. It is also used by the Interior Ministry and security agencies due to its small size.

%c[255,1,255,255]ï%c[default] scope installation is not possible due to the lack of a dovetail mount
 

%c[255,1,255,255]ï%c[default] PBS-4 silencer
 
The shortened AK-74 assault rifle was developed in the late 1970s and early 1980s for use in combat vehicles, aircraft and by gun crews as well as paratroopers. It is also used by the Interior Ministry and security agencies due to its small size.
AKS-74U with Cobra EKP-1S-03 collimator, PBS-4 silencer and a 45-round magazine.

%c[255,1,255,255]ï%c[default] NATO silencer
 
The Steyr AUG (Armee Universal Gewehr - Army Universal Rifle) is a compact, lightweight rifle made in 1977 by the Austrian company Steyr-Daimler-Puch. This rifle uses bullpup layout with the magazine and bolt assembly behind the grip and trigger.
British-made Sniper rifle, developed by Accuracy International.

The M90 is a high-caliber sniper rifle created in 1990 by the American company Barrett Firearms. The main differences from its predecessor (M82A1) are manual operation, fixed barrel and bullpup layout, which made the rifle more compact, reliable and inexpensive. In 1995, the M95 rifle was introduced, which featured a modified trigger guard and a 25mm forward-mounted pistol grip.
American sniper rifle manufactured by the Barrett Firearms company. Barrett M98 model Bravo rifle (never put into production) was designed for .338 Lapua Magnum cartridge (8.6x70mm or 8.58x70mm).

%c[255,1,255,255]ï%c[default] 9mm silencer
 
The Cz-75 is a pistol developed in Czechoslovakia in 1975. It is widely used all over the world. In the Czech Republic it is mainly used by the police (the military uses CZ 83).

%c[255,1,255,255]ï%c[default] scope for Galil
 

%c[255,1,255,255]ï%c[default] PBS-1 silencer
 
The Galil is an Israeli assault rifle developed by designer Israel Galili on the basis of the Finnish Valmet Rk 62, which in turn is a variant of the Kalashnikov assault rifle.

%c[255,1,255,255]ï%c[default] NATO silencer
 
The HK G3 is a german assault rifle, adopted by the German Army in 1959. In 1995 it was replaced by the NATO HK G36 5.56mm assault rifle.
G3SG1 is a sniper rifle for civilian and police use. Some models are equipped with an adjustable cheek rest, a folding bipod and an adjustable trigger.

The PSG1 rifle was developed as a response to the Munich massacre that took place at the 1972 Summer Olympics. At that time, the West German police failed to eliminate the terrorists quickly enough to prevent the murder of the hostages. Heckler & Koch was commissioned to create a semi-automatic rifle with high accuracy and large magazine capacity. Heckler & Koch produced the 7.62mm semi-automatic sniper rifle PSG1 in the mid-1980s, which was mainly used by police and special forces.

A semi-automatic pistol, created and manufactured by the Belgian company Fabrique Nationale of Herstal. The name is a combination, on one hand Five-seveN means "5-7" (5.7 caliber, which is equal to .224), and on the other hand the first and last letters, capitalized, are the abbreviation of the Fabrique Nationale company.

%c[255,1,255,255]ï%c[default] GemTech silencer
 
FN FNP is a semi-automatic pistol developed by FNH-USA (American division of Belgian FN Herstal). It has been in production since early 2006.

The FNX rifles are produced in the USA by FNH USA, a local division of the famous Belgian company FN Herstal. FN FNX rifles were developed in 2007-2009 as part of US Joint Combat Pistol Program to develop new rifles for US armed forces. The program was not a success, but the FNX rifles were introduced commercially within the US military and police markets, as well as in many other countries.
Russian-made semi-automatic pistol. Developed by a team of designers under the leadership of V.A. Yarygin, mass-produced at the Izhevsk Mechanical Plant.
The 1933 Pistol (TT means Tulsky, Tokarev. GRAU Index- 56-A-132) is the first semi-automatic Soviet Army pistol, developed in 1930 by Soviet designer Fyodor Vasilievich Tokarev.

%c[255,1,255,255]ï%c[default] 9mm silencer
 
The OTs-33 "Pernach" is a Russian-made automatic pistol developed in the mid-1990s by the Central Design Bureau of the SOO under the leadership of I.Ya. Stechkin to replace the Soviet-era APS. At the time of development the gun was referred to as "AP SBZ-2" ("automatic pistol designed by I.Ya. Stechkin, A.V. Balzer, A.V. Zinchenko")

The GSh-18 is a Russian pistol developed in the late 1990s at the Tula Instrument Design Bureau. It was named after the first letters of the names of the designers under whose supervision it was designed (Vasily Petrovich Gryazev and Arkady Georgievich Shipunov) and the number "18", indicating magazine capacity.

The Glock 17 is an Austrian pistol developed by Glock for the needs of the Austrian Army. It was the first weapon developed by this company. The resulting weapon turned out to be quite successful and easy to use, so it was later adopted by the Austrian Army under the designation P80. Thanks to its combat characteristics and reliability it is widely used as a civilian self-defense weapon.

%c[255,1,255,255]ï%c[default] GemTech silencer
 
In 1988 a compact variation of the Glock 17, the Glock 19, was introduced for the civilian market, as well as for the armament of various special services and military officers. Of course, the compact variation of already very successful full-size model was to become just as popular in the gun market. And it did, the Glock 19 quickly became very popular among police and civilians, who bought compact pistols for concealed carry for self-defense and sport shooting.

%c[255,1,255,255]ï%c[default] Cobra EKP-1S-03, Cobra EKP-8-02, 1P29 "Tulpan", PSO-1 scopes
 

%c[255,1,255,255]ï%c[default] PBS-1 silencer
 
"Saiga-12K", a shortened semi-automatic shotgun, is a "smoothbore carbine". The stock and pistol grip (and in some versions, the forend) are borrowed from the Kalashnikov assault rifle. It also features a locking mechanism, which prevents the safety from being disengaged until the buttstock is folded out.

In 1944 the Degtyarev design, known as the RD-44, came out on top in competitive testing. The RD-44 machine gun was produced in small batches until the end of the war and was tested by the troops. Shortly after the war an upgraded version of this machine gun, adapted to the 7.62x39mm cartridge that became standard, was adopted by the Soviet Army as the "Degtyarev Rifle System (RPD)".

%c[255,1,255,255]ï%c[default] scope installation is not possible due to the lack of a dovetail mount
 
The RPK (Kalashnikov Rifle) was developed as a support weapon for infantry platoons based on the AKM assault rifle, and was in service with Soviet Armed Forces and many other countries. Until now it is still in service with Russian Armed Forces and Ministry of Internal Affairs. The Soviet army had one RPK for every rifle platoon (consisting of 10 men). The RPK has been mostly replaced by RPK-74 in the Russian Armed Forces.

%c[255,1,255,255]ï%c[default] Cobra EKP-1S-03, Cobra EKP-8-02, 1P29 "Tulpan", PSO-1 scopes
 

%c[255,1,255,255]ï%c[default] TGP-A silencer
 
A machine gun designed to replace the RPK 7.62x39mm cartridge machine gun in the army as part of the small arms system designed for the 5.45x39mm intermediate cartridge. It was adopted for service in 1974 along with the AK-74 assault rifle.

%c[255,1,255,255]ï%c[default] 9mm silencer
 
This series of pistols has a worldwide reputation as a reliable, albeit somewhat bulky weapon. It is used by army and police forces of many countries. Not less popular among the criminals because of its powerful cartridge and high-capacity magazine. Typically older models of this gun make their way into the Zone.

This shotgun is an ordinary hunting rifle with horizontal barrels, much more compact and lightweight than a conventional double-barreled rifle. One of the most common weapons among the bandits, as it is convenient for concealed carry and very effective in close combat.

%c[255,1,255,255]ï%c[default] .45 .cal silencer
 
Upgraded 1911 pistol, which became a classic of automatic weapons and honorably served in all the armed conflicts of the twentieth century. Both the original and modified versions are still in production by dozens if not hundreds of manufacturers. The only drawback is its low magazine capacity, but it is compensated by the powerful cartridge.
Upgraded Colt M1911A1 from the Kimber company.

A real pocket cannon - big, heavy and very destructive. It was developed as a specialized weapon for hunting medium and large game, as well as for sport shooting at silhouette targets at a distance of fifty meters or more. It is not very popular in the Zone due to its price and size.
Variatio of the Desert Eagle with a Docter Sight collimator, a recoil-reducing compensator and a unique finish.

%c[255,1,255,255]ï%c[default] ACOG, Barska ES AC10632, Barska Red Dot AC11090, C-more Railway Tactical, EOTech scopes
 

%c[255,1,255,255]ï%c[default] NATO silencer
 
FAMAS is a French 5.56mm caliber assault rifle with a bullpup layout, developed by the MAS weapon company in Saint-Etienne. Its unofficial name is "Le Clairon".

%c[255,1,255,255]ï%c[default] NATO silencer
 
This futuristic-looking weapon is a modular, mass-produced assault rifle and grenade launcher system. Despite its bulky appearance, it is highly ergonomic, easy to fire in all modes, and highly reliable.

%c[255,1,255,255]ï%c[default] Cobra EKP-1S-03, Cobra EKP-8-02, 1P29 "Tulpan", PSO-1 scopes
 

%c[255,1,255,255]ï%c[default] PBS-1 silencer
 
The PP-19 "Bison" is a submachine gun developed in 1993 by V. M. Kalashnikov (son of designer M. T. Kalashnikov) and Aleksey Dragunov (son of E. F. Dragunov) at the request of the Russian Interior Ministry (MVD).

%c[255,1,255,255]ï%c[default] ACOG, Barska ES AC10632, Barska Red Dot AC11090, C-more Railway Tactical, EOTech scopes
 

%c[255,1,255,255]ï%c[default] silencer .57
 
The FN P90 is a Belgian self-defense submachine gun, developed in 1986-1987 by FN Herstal. It was primarily designed for tank crews and drivers of combat vehicles. It has an advanced and comfortable ergonomic design. The 5.7x28mm SS190 cartridge was specifically designed for P90, with high penetration and low ricochet.

%c[255,1,255,255]ï%c[default] 9mm silencer
 
Ukrainian-made pistol, designed mainly for law enforcement and security agencies. It has better accuracy, handling, and magazine capacity than the PM. It mostly got into the "Zone" among the junk guns that are widely sold here. Nevertheless, it is in demand among the stalkers because of its quite good performance.

%c[255,1,255,255]ï%c[default] 9mm silencer
 
Ukrainian semi-automatic pistol chambered for 9x18mm PM cartridge. Developed in the spring of 2004, produced by RPC "Fort".

%c[255,1,255,255]ï%c[default] NATO silencer
 

%c[255,1,255,255]ï%c[default] AG36 underbarrel grenade launcher
 
This is the epitome of the new trends in Western automatic weapons: the mechanism is now based on a short stroke gas piston instead of a semi-automatic bolt. The changes have clearly paid off: this assault rifle is a first-class example of modern weapon - lightweight, reliable and ergonomic.

%c[255,1,255,255]ï%c[default] ACOG, Barska ES AC10632, Barska Red Dot AC11090, C-more Railway Tactical, EOTech scopes
 

%c[255,1,255,255]ï%c[default] NATO silencer
 
The G36 is a shortened version of the German G36 rifle. The Rifle was developed in 1996 by the German weapons company Heckler & Koch.

%c[255,1,255,255]ï%c[default] NATO silencer
 
The G36K (Kurz) is a shortened G36 rifle, with a 318mm barrel.

A super-accurate hi-tech weapon known as item 62, this rifle was developed in secret laboratories located inside the Zone. The weapon operates by accelerating bullets to extremely high speeds using a system of electromagnets, which provides incredible stopping power with virtually no recoil. The weapon is powered by using capsulated artifact fragments in the batteries.

%c[255,1,255,255]ï%c[default] scope œŒ4ı34
 
A grenade launcher system with 70% of it being an AK-74 type assault rifle. The main differences are 9x39mm caliber, bullpup layout and wider upgrade options. It is designed to be used by the rapid response troops, and is one of the most popular AK-74-style rifles in the world. It is highly valued by military and stalkers for its ability to reliably engage enemy in body armor and behind cover.

%c[255,1,255,255]ï%c[default] 9mm silencer
 
A modified 20th century pistol. Despite its respectable age, the popularity of this model is still very high all over the world.

%c[255,1,255,255]ï%c[default] ACOG, Barska ES AC10632, Barska Red Dot AC11090, C-more Railway Tactical, EOTech scopes
 

%c[255,1,255,255]ï%c[default] M203 underbarrel grenade launcher
 

%c[255,1,255,255]ï%c[default] NATO silencer
 
HK416 0 automatic rifle, designed by German company Heckler & Koch, is based on the M4 carbine. Initially the new weapon was to be an interchangeable module for mounting on any M4 or M16 rifle lower receiver, but later full-fledged rifles also became available. The name HK416 symbolizes the continuation of the M4 and M16 rifles.

%c[255,1,255,255]ï%c[default] NATO silencer
 
The SA80 (SA-80 - Small Arms for 1980s) is a British small arms system, made in the mid-1980s, consisting of the L85 assault rifle, the L86 light machine gun, the L22 short machine gun and the L98 training rifle. It is used by the British Army.

%c[255,1,255,255]ï%c[default] ACOG, Barska ES AC10632, Barska Red Dot AC11090, C-more Railway Tactical, EOTech scopes
 

%c[255,1,255,255]ï%c[default] M203 underbarrel grenade launcher
 

%c[255,1,255,255]ï%c[default] NATO silencer
 
A new step in the development of the famous line of rifles. In fact, only the top half of the receiver with the barrel, gas piston and bolt assembly has been changed, resulting in improved ergonomics and reliability, while weight has been reduced. This rifle features high accuracy, although its high sensitivity to dirt makes it unsuitable for use in the harsh conditions of the Zone.
This is one of the most common pump-action shotguns. It was first produced in 1962. It is now available in various modifications for hunting as well as for police, guards and self-defense.

The MP-133 is a russian smoothbore shotgun used for various types of hunting, sport shooting, security and self-defense. The gun was developed on the basis of the IZh-81 shotgun and has been serially produced by the Izhevsk Mechanical Plant since 2000.
MP-153 is a russian semi-automatic smooth-bore shotgun, popularly referred to as the "murka". Used for various types of hunting, sport shooting, law enforcement and self-defense.

%c[255,1,255,255]ï%c[default] ACOG, Barska ES AC10632, Barska Red Dot AC11090, C-more Railway Tactical, EOTech scopes
 

%c[255,1,255,255]ï%c[default] M203 underbarrel grenade launcher
 

%c[255,1,255,255]ï%c[default] NATO silencer
 
The M16A2-based assault rifle was originally developed in the USA for use in combat vehicles and support troops. It is now being used by the entire U.S. Army, as the convenience of the shortened carbine in today's environment, where most of the Army is composed of motorized infantry, combat vehicles crews and support troops, more than compensates for the rather small decline in its performance compared to a fully-fledged rifle.

%c[255,1,255,255]ï%c[default] ACOG, Barska ES AC10632, Barska Red Dot AC11090, C-more Railway Tactical, EOTech scopes
 

%c[255,1,255,255]ï%c[default] M203 underbarrel grenade launcher
 

%c[255,1,255,255]ï%c[default] NATO silencer
 
In 1996 the M4A1 carbine was developed on the basis of the M16A3 rifle for the Special Operations Forces, and was distinguished by the return to fully-automatic fire instead of the three-shot burst.

%c[255,1,255,255]ï%c[default] ACOG, Barska ES AC10632, Barska Red Dot AC11090, C-more Railway Tactical, EOTech scopes
 

%c[255,1,255,255]ï%c[default] M203 underbarrel grenade launcher
 

%c[255,1,255,255]ï%c[default] NATO silencer
 
M16 (Official designation is Rifle, Caliber 5.56 mm, M16) is ‡ 5.56 mm automatic rifle developed on the basis of AR-15 rifle and adopted for service in 1960s. The M16 and its rifles to this day remain the main weapon of the US infantry. It is one of the most common firearms in the world - more than 8 million have been made.

M16A1 - upgraded version of the M16. Main differences are the appearance of the forward assist and the breechblock buffer (reduced rate of fire to 750-850 rounds per minute and prevented blowback and misfires), more reliable flash suppressor with closed slits, chromed coating of the bolt (to prevent corrosion), reduction of barrel length from 356 to 305mm (improved bullet stability, but increased dispersion at ranges above 400 meters), and an add-on for bayonet installation. It also featured a 30-round magazine and silencer, designed to fire regular (but not subsonic) cartridges. It was in service with US Army from 1967 to 1985.

%c[255,1,255,255]ï%c[default] M203 underbarrel grenade launcher
 

%c[255,1,255,255]ï%c[default] NATO silencer
 
M16A2 is a further development of the M16A1 rifle adapted for SS109/M855 cartridge. It differed from M16A1 by having a hardened barrel, new handguards and a buttstock made from impact-resistant polyamide, new automatic 3 shot burst fire mode, new flash supressor with slits in the upper part only, new forend and buttstock made from polyamide, new lightweight 30-round magazine, which helped to compensate for the loss of automatic fire. The new rifle was equipped with lightweight plastic magazines for 30 cartridges.

The M16A3 is a variation of the M16A2 rifle with an automatic fire mode, and is in service with the Navy. The carrying handle and the triggerguard are identical to the M16A2. It was introduced in 1992 as the M16A2E3.

The M16A4 is a variation of the M16A2 rifle. The top of the receiver has a Picatinny rail instead of the carrying handle (which became removable). Additional Picatinny rails can be installed on the forend.
Variation of M16A4 with desert camouflaged and Leupold Mark4 scope.
The M79 is a single-shot 40mm grenade launcher adopted by the US Army in 1961. It was developed between 1951 and 1961 by the Springfield Armory Corporation of America. Unofficial name is "Thumper".

%c[255,1,255,255]ï%c[default] ACOG, Barska ES AC10632, Barska Red Dot AC11090, C-more Railway Tactical, EOTech scopes
 
The caliber 5.56x45mm handheld machine gun manufactured by the Fabrique Nationale (Belgium), mass production began in the 1980s. The development of this weapon was given to the promising designer Ernest Vervier, creator of the FN MAG machine gun.

%c[255,1,255,255]ï%c[default] ACOG, Barska ES AC10632, Barska Red Dot AC11090, C-more Railway Tactical, EOTech scopes
 

%c[255,1,255,255]ï%c[default] 9mm silencer
 
This submachine gun is justifiably popular because of its reliability, ease of handling and high accuracy. It was adopted by the army and police units of many countries and appeared on the black market, eventually making its way to the Zone.

%c[255,1,255,255]ï%c[default] ACOG, Barska ES AC10632, Barska Red Dot AC11090, C-more Railway Tactical, EOTech scopes
 

%c[255,1,255,255]ï%c[default] NATO silencer
 
The HK UMP (Universale Maschinenpistole) is a submachine gun developed by the German company Heckler & Koch in the 1990s, as an addition to the HK MP5 family of submachine guns.

%c[255,1,255,255]ï%c[default] ACOG, Barska ES AC10632, Barska Red Dot AC11090, C-more Railway Tactical, EOTech scopes
 
The MP5SD is a 1974 model MP5 with an integrated silencer.

%c[255,1,255,255]ï%c[default] ACOG, Barska ES AC10632, Barska Red Dot AC11090, C-more Railway Tactical, EOTech scopes
 

%c[255,1,255,255]ï%c[default] 9mm silencer
 
The PP-2000 is a Russian 9mm submachine gun developed by a team of designers from the Tula-based instrument-making design bureau (by Prof. V.P.Gryazev, specialists B.I.Kuznetsov and A.I.Rasskazov). The PP-2000 is advertised as a weapon for law enforcement units operating in urban environment and also as a personal defense weapon for certain categories of military personnel.

This pistol was developed in the second half of the twentieth century based on the PM pistol for reconnaissance teams and secret service personnel. This model is considered obsolete, but it is still a very effective weapon in capable hands.

This Soviet legacy is the most common pistol in the Zone and is one of the best compact self-defense handguns available. It is small, highly reliable, easy to use and maintain in working order. It also suffers from several drawbacks, including its short range, low firing accuracy and poor stopping power, while also losing out to modern pistols in its class in terms of weight and magazine size.
An ancient PMm received by Degtyarev as a reward for "Succesful execution of highly dangerous state orders, as well as valor and courage shown in the line of duty."

The modernized 9mm Makarov PMm pistol (GRAU index - 56-A-125M) is a Russian pistol developed in the early 1990s as part of the "Grach" R&D project. Took part in the competition for a new army pistol under the designation "Grach-3".

A smoothbore combat revolver-type shotgun intended to provide extreme firepower for militarized units. The weapon benefits from a large magazine and a high effective rate of fire, but its bulkiness and considerable weight, combined with a long reload time, are the price to be paid for these advantages. Rare in the Zone and is used primarily to clear closed spaces of mutants.

%c[255,1,255,255]ï%c[default] Barska ES AC10632, Barska Red Dot AC11090, C-more Railway Tactical, EOTech scopes
 
The Remington 870 is an American shotgun first introduced by Remington Arms in 1950. It is one of the most famous pump-action shotguns in the world, thanks to its distinctive reloading action. Produced in various versions, it is suitable for military and police, as well as hunters and sportsmen, and for self-defense.

This revolver-type grenade launcher uses six rifled front-loading barrels, identical to underbarrel launcher attachments. The drum is also front-loading. Widely used for rapid suppression of enemy firing position and, when in the open, attacking defended fixed targets or fighting particularly tough monsters.

A handheld modification of the army's belt-fed machine gun. Despite its weight and low precision, this LMG has found admirers in the Zone. Used primarily to fight off outnumbering enemy forces and to clear out mutant lairs.

The 7.62mm PKP Pecheneg machine gun (GRAU index - 6P41) is a Russian machine gun based on the PKM. It is designed to destroy enemy personnel, vehicles and air targets. It was developed by TsNIITochMash.

A grenade launcher from the 1960s, which was left in huge quantities in the army warehouses and made its way into the Zone. This weapon is a recoilless smooth-bore single-shot grenade launcher. Although its huge size and weight make it an unlikely choice for stalkers, given its huge destructive power and ease of use, it has found admirers in the Zone.

%c[255,1,255,255]ï%c[default] .45 .cal silencer
 
The only model of the world's most popular pistol left in serial production. This gun is characterized by excellent ergonomics and accuracy. Small magazine capacity is compensated by powerful cartridge and reliability of a Swiss watch. Unsurprisingly, this pistol is in high demand among seasoned stalkers and mercenaries.

%c[255,1,255,255]ï%c[default] ACOG, Barska ES AC10632, Barska Red Dot AC11090, C-more Railway Tactical, EOTech scopes
 

%c[255,1,255,255]ï%c[default] M203 underbarrel grenade launcher
 

%c[255,1,255,255]ï%c[default] NATO silencer
 
A relatively new assault rifle model. It is one of the best weapons in its class due to its high reliability, accuracy, and ease of handling. Despite being relatively difficult to obtain in the Zone, this assault rifle is often ordered by experienced stalkers at considerable expense

At first glance it is obvious that this rifle has seen some action, but its previous owner treated it with care. The rifle was has been taken apart and put back together, with every component fine-tuned for optimum performance: some parts are made of lighter alloys, which undoubtedly improved accuracy and the reduced weight of the rifle, but had an impact on the durability. The letter "S" has been carved into the stock, along with 16 small notches.

A relatively new assault rifle model. It is one of the best weapons in its class due to its high reliability, accuracy, and ease of handling. Despite being relatively difficult to obtain in the Zone, this assault rifle is often ordered by experienced stalkers at considerable expense.

%c[255,1,255,255]ï%c[default] ACOG, Barska ES AC10632, Barska Red Dot AC11090, C-more Railway Tactical, EOTech scopes
 

%c[255,1,255,255]ï%c[default] NATO silencer
 
The SG-552 Commando is a compact assault rifle with a 226mm long barrel, designed for special police units. Unlike the SG 550, the recoil spring is located behind the bolt carrier and acts directly on the bolt, not on the piston rod. The rifle is fitted with a modified flash hider and can be fitted with Picatinny rails for mounting additional accessories.

%c[255,1,255,255]ï%c[default] ACOG, Barska ES AC10632, Barska Red Dot AC11090, C-more Railway Tactical, EOTech scopes
 

%c[255,1,255,255]ï%c[default] M203 underbarrel grenade launcher
 

%c[255,1,255,255]ï%c[default] NATO silencer
 
FN SCAR (Special Operations Forces Combat Assault Rifle) is a weapon system developed by the US division of the Belgian company FN Herstal for participation in the USSOCOM competition for a new assault rifle in 2004.

The Franchi SPAS-12 (Special Purpose Automatic Shotgun) is an Italian shotgun developed in the late 1970s. It is a dual-mode shotgun, which means it can be used as a semi-automatic or pump-action weapon. It can be operated by pressing the button under the forend, and moving the forend slightly forward or backward until it clicks into place.
The USAS-12 is an automatic shotgun developed by John Trevor in the late 1980s, based on the ideas of another American designer, MacSwell Atchisson, who created the Atchisson Assault Shotgun.

%c[255,1,255,255]ï%c[default] M203 underbarrel grenade launcher
 

%c[255,1,255,255]ï%c[default] G&P SR-25 Silencer
 
The SR-25 is a semi-automatic sniper rifle developed by Eugene Stoner in the 1990s, based on the design of the AR-15 rifle.

Russian magazine-fed sniper rifle developed in 1998-2000 by a team of designers led by Vladimir Stronsky and serially produced by Izhmash Concern. The SV-98 is designed to engage incoming, mobile, exposed or armored enemy personnel at a range of up to 1000 meters.

%c[255,1,255,255]ï%c[default] Cobra EKP-1S-03, Cobra EKP-8-02, 1P29 "Tulpan" scopes
 

%c[255,1,255,255]ï%c[default] KZRZP silencer
 
This type of sniper rifle has been in the arms market for half a century and during this time has managed to prove itself as an extremely reliable and easy to handle weapon. In the army it serves mainly for engaging distant targets that cannot be hit with a machine gun, but stalkers have praised the SVD for the fact that its bullet can penetrate even the thickest mutant skin or body armor.

The 7.62mm Tokarev semi-automatic rifle (SVT-40), also known as the 1940 Tokarev automatic rifle, is a variant of the Soviet semi-automatic rifle designed by F.V.Tokarev. The SVT-38 was developed as a replacement for the Simonov automatic rifle, and was adopted by the Red Army on February 26, 1939. The first SVT of 1938 was made on July 16, 1939. Since October 1, 1939 it was mass-produced at Tula factory, and since 1940 - at Izhevsk weapon factory.

%c[255,1,255,255]ï%c[default] Cobra EKP-1S-03, Cobra EKP-8-02, 1P29 "Tulpan" scopes
 
A more modern variant of the SVD sniper rifle with a bullpup design for reduced size. It has higher rate of fire than its parent rifle while weighing less, yet accuracy at close and medium ranges remains about the same. Today it enjoys well-deserved popularity in the military and among stalkers.
TOZ-194 is a russian pump shotgun developed in the mid-1990s, based on the TOZ-94 design. It is manufactured at the Tula Arms Plant.

A very popular vertical double-barrelled shotgun. Thanks to acceptable accuracy and good stopping power, it provides better protection against mutants than a pistol. The shotgun very cheap and affordable compared to most weapons, therefore it is widely used by rookies and bandits on the outskirts of the Zone.

A very popular vertical double-barrelled shotgun. Thanks to acceptable accuracy and good stopping power, it provides better protection against mutants than a pistol. The shotgun very cheap and affordable compared to most weapons, therefore it is widely used by rookies and bandits on the outskirts of the Zone.

The TOZ-66 double-barrelled hunting shotgun was produced from 1967 to 1978 and is intended for hunting and recreational use. It was developed on the basis of TOZ-63 shotgun and differs by the reinforced receiver.

TheTOZ-66 double-barrelled hunting shotgun was produced from 1967 to 1978 and is intended for hunting and recreational use. It was developed on the basis of TOZ-63 shotgun and differs by the reinforced receiver
Welcome to RAD Multiplayer! Descriptions by MonoKit

%c[255,1,255,255]ï%c[default] .45 .cal silencer
 
This weapon's main distinguishing features are high reliability and survivability with excellent accuracy. Despite some shortcomings (a rather big size, high center of mass and massive bolt that makes concealed carry difficult) it is very popular among the Zone veterans.

%c[255,1,255,255]ï%c[default] .45 .cal silencer
 
HK USP sports pistol. It has a special nozzle, which reduces the recoil of the barrel when firing due to its weight.

%c[255,1,255,255]ï%c[default] Cobra EKP-1S-03, Cobra EKP-8-02, 1P29 "Tulpan", PSO-1Ã2-01 scopes
 

%c[255,1,255,255]ï%c[default] integrated silencer
 
This weapon is based on the VSS special sniper rifle as a silenced weapon for special forces. It allows the shooter to fire effectively at an enemy protected by body armor without revealing their position. One of the main features is the use of an integrated silencer and the 9x39mm caliber cartridge with a heavy bullet.

%c[255,1,255,255]ï%c[default] Cobra EKP-1S-03, Cobra EKP-8-02, 1P29 "Tulpan", PSO-1Ã2-01 scopes
 

%c[255,1,255,255]ï%c[default] silencer for SP-3
 
The SP-3 Vikhr is a compact Russian assault rifle developed at the Klimov Central Research Institute for Precision Machine Building by designers A. D. Borisov and V. N. Levchenko in 1994. The rifle was further developed by the designer A.I.Tashlykov and was put into mass production in 1996. It is based on the AS "Val" silenced assault rifle, with which it shares the same basic parts and has a positive effect on the production and operation of the weapon.

%c[255,1,255,255]ï%c[default] Cobra EKP-1S-03, Cobra EKP-8-02, 1P29 "Tulpan" scopes
 
The 9mm special sniper rifle, known as the VSS, was developed based on the "Vintorez" thematic, which has given the rifle its name This silent sniper rifle was developed at the "Tochmash" central research institute in Klimovsk in the early 80s under the leadership of Pyotr Ivanovich Serdyukov. It's used by special operations forces.

"Vyhlop" (Special high-caliber sniper rifle) is a silenced bulpup high-caliber sniper rifle. The main purpose of the VSSK is low-noise and flashless destruction of lightly armored vehicles as well as personnel in protective equipment, such as heavy body armor. Its effective range is up to 600 meters.

%c[255,1,255,255]ï%c[default] Cobra EKP-1S-03, Cobra EKP-8-02, 1P29 "Tulpan", PSO-1Ã2-01 scopes
 

%c[255,1,255,255]ï%c[default] Silencer for 9¿-91/¬— -94
 
The VSK 94 Military Sniper Complex, GRAU index 6B8) is a Russian sniper rifle based on the 9A-91 submachine gun. It is used for conducting silent sniper operations which require low noise and flashless fire.

%c[255,1,255,255]ï%c[default] Cobra EKP-1S-03, Cobra EKP-8-02, 1P29 "Tulpan", PSO-1 scopes
 

%c[255,1,255,255]ï%c[default] PBS-1 silencer
 
The "Vepr-12" Molot is a Russian smoothbore semi-automatic carbine based on the Kalashnikov rifle. It is intended for hunting, sports (generally on an open range), self-defense as well as military applications. It is the direct competitor to the Saiga-12 rifle.

%c[255,1,255,255]ï%c[default] 9mm silencer
 
An excellent Western pistol, characterized by high reliability, a generous magazine, good accuracy, and perhaps the best ergonomics among its contemporaries. This pistol enjoys great popularity among both veterans and newcommers with cash to spare.
The WA2000 (Walter Automat 2000) is a bulpup sniper rifle developed by the Walther arms concerns. A total of 176 were ever produced (it's a great mystery where Nimble got this rifle from).
This western pump-action smoothbore shotgun is widely popular due to its reliability and high fire-rate. All parts of this weapon were coated with an anti-corrosion coating.
